premises:
All employees who schedule a meeting with their customers will go to the company building today. 
Everyone who has lunch in the company building schedules meetings with their customers. 
Employees have lunch either in the company building or at home.
If an employee has lunch at home, they are working remotely from home.
All employees who are in other countries work remotely from home. 
No managers work remotely from home. 
James will appear in the company today if and only if he is a manager.
conclusion: If James is either a manager or in other countries,  then James does not either has lunch at home or work remotely from home. If James either has lunch at home or works remotely from home, then he is neither a manager nor does he work in other countries. [contrapositive is more natural]
lean_code:
structure Context where
  Person : Type
  James : Person
  Employee : Person → Prop
  Manager : Person → Prop
  InOtherCountries : Person → Prop
  LunchHome : Person → Prop
  LunchBuilding : Person → Prop
  Remote : Person → Prop
  Schedules : Person → Prop
  GoBuilding : Person → Prop
  AppearCompany : Person → Prop
  -- Premises
  A1 : ∀ x, (Employee x ∧ Schedules x) → GoBuilding x
  A2 : ∀ x, LunchBuilding x → Schedules x
  A3 : ∀ x, Employee x → (LunchBuilding x ∨ LunchHome x)
  A4 : ∀ x, Employee x → LunchHome x → Remote x
  A5 : ∀ x, (Employee x ∧ InOtherCountries x) → Remote x
  A6 : ∀ x, Manager x → ¬ Remote x
  A7 : AppearCompany James ↔ Manager James

def Target (C : Context) : Prop :=
  (C.Manager C.James ∨ C.InOtherCountries C.James) → ¬ (C.LunchHome C.James ∨ C.Remote C.James)

-- A model where the premises hold and Target is false
def worldFalse : Context := {
  Person := Unit
  James := Unit.unit
  Employee := fun _ => False
  Manager := fun _ => True
  InOtherCountries := fun _ => False
  LunchHome := fun _ => True
  LunchBuilding := fun _ => False
  Remote := fun _ => False
  Schedules := fun _ => False
  GoBuilding := fun _ => False
  AppearCompany := fun _ => True
  A1 := by
    intro x h
    exact False.elim h.left
  A2 := by
    intro x hb
    exact False.elim hb
  A3 := by
    intro x hE
    exact False.elim hE
  A4 := by
    intro x hE hLH
    exact False.elim hE
  A5 := by
    intro x h
    exact False.elim h.left
  A6 := by
    intro x hM
    intro r
    exact False.elim r
  A7 := by
    apply Iff.intro
    · intro _; exact True.intro
    · intro _; exact True.intro
}

theorem target_false_in_worldFalse : ¬ Target worldFalse := by
  intro h
  have ante : worldFalse.Manager worldFalse.James ∨ worldFalse.InOtherCountries worldFalse.James :=
    Or.inl True.intro
  have disj : worldFalse.LunchHome worldFalse.James ∨ worldFalse.Remote worldFalse.James :=
    Or.inl True.intro
  have notDisj := h ante
  exact notDisj disj

-- A model where the premises hold and Target is true
def worldTrue : Context := {
  Person := Unit
  James := Unit.unit
  Employee := fun _ => False
  Manager := fun _ => False
  InOtherCountries := fun _ => False
  LunchHome := fun _ => False
  LunchBuilding := fun _ => False
  Remote := fun _ => False
  Schedules := fun _ => False
  GoBuilding := fun _ => False
  AppearCompany := fun _ => False
  A1 := by
    intro x h
    exact False.elim h.left
  A2 := by
    intro x hb
    exact False.elim hb
  A3 := by
    intro x hE
    exact False.elim hE
  A4 := by
    intro x hE hLH
    exact False.elim hE
  A5 := by
    intro x h
    exact False.elim h.left
  A6 := by
    intro x hM
    cases hM
  A7 := by
    apply Iff.intro
    · intro h; cases h
    · intro h; cases h
}

theorem target_true_in_worldTrue : Target worldTrue := by
  intro h
  cases h with
  | inl m => cases m
  | inr o => cases o

-- Therefore Target is neither universally provable nor refutable from the premises
theorem not_universally_true : ¬ (∀ C : Context, Target C) := by
  intro h
  have t := h worldFalse
  exact target_false_in_worldFalse t

theorem not_universally_false : ¬ (∀ C : Context, ¬ Target C) := by
  intro h
  have t := h worldTrue
  exact t target_true_in_worldTrue

premises:
Symphony No. 9 is a music piece.
Composers write music pieces.
Beethoven wrote Symphony No. 9.
Vienna Music Society premiered Symphony No. 9.
Vienna Music Society is an orchestra.
Beethoven leads the Vienna Music Society.
Orchestras are led by conductors.
lean_code:
universe u

-- Types for entities
axiom Person : Type
axiom Orchestra : Type
axiom MusicPiece : Type

-- Specific constants from the context
axiom Beethoven : Person
axiom ViennaMusicSociety : Orchestra
axiom Symphony9 : MusicPiece

-- Predicates/relations
axiom Composer : Person → Prop
axiom Conductor : Person → Prop
axiom Leads : Person → Orchestra → Prop
axiom Writes : Person → MusicPiece → Prop
axiom Premiered : Orchestra → MusicPiece → Prop

-- Premises from the textual context
-- "Composers write music pieces." (interpreted: every composer has written some music piece)
axiom composers_write_musicpieces :
  ∀ p : Person, Composer p → ∃ m : MusicPiece, Writes p m

-- "Beethoven wrote Symphony No. 9."
axiom beethoven_wrote_symphony9 : Writes Beethoven Symphony9

-- "Vienna Music Society premiered Symphony No. 9."
axiom vms_premiered_symphony9 : Premiered ViennaMusicSociety Symphony9

-- "Beethoven leads the Vienna Music Society."
axiom beethoven_leads_vms : Leads Beethoven ViennaMusicSociety

-- "Orchestras are led by conductors." (if someone leads an orchestra, then they are a conductor)
axiom leaders_of_orchestras_are_conductors :
  ∀ p : Person, ∀ o : Orchestra, Leads p o → Conductor p

-- Derivable facts (not about being a composer)
theorem beethoven_is_conductor : Conductor Beethoven := by
  exact leaders_of_orchestras_are_conductors Beethoven ViennaMusicSociety beethoven_leads_vms

theorem beethoven_wrote_a_musicpiece : ∃ m : MusicPiece, Writes Beethoven m := by
  exact Exists.intro Symphony9 beethoven_wrote_symphony9

premises:
All of Zaha Hadid's design styles that Max adores have interesting geometries.
No brutalist buildings that Max adores have interesting geometries.
Every style that Max adores is either Zaha Hadid's design style or Kelly Wearstler's design style. 
All of Kelly Wearstler's design styles that Max adores are evocative.
All of Kelly Wearstler's design styles that Max adores are dreamy.
If a design by Max that he adores has interesting geometries, then the design is a brutalist building and evocative.
conclusion: A design by Max is evocative and dreamy.
lean_code:
universe u

-- Universe of discourse and predicates
def Premises (U : Type u) (A I B E D Z K M : U → Prop) : Prop :=
  (∀ x, (Z x ∧ A x) → I x) ∧
  (∀ x, (B x ∧ A x) → ¬ I x) ∧
  (∀ x, A x → (Z x ∨ K x)) ∧
  (∀ x, (K x ∧ A x) → E x) ∧
  (∀ x, (K x ∧ A x) → D x) ∧
  (∀ x, (M x ∧ A x ∧ I x) → (B x ∧ E x))

def Conclusion (U : Type u) (A I B E D Z K M : U → Prop) : Prop :=
  ∃ x, M x ∧ E x ∧ D x

-- Countermodel where all premises hold but the conclusion is false
theorem model_false :
  ∃ (U : Type) (A I B E D Z K M : U → Prop),
    Premises U A I B E D Z K M ∧ ¬ Conclusion U A I B E D Z K M := by
  refine ⟨Unit,
          (fun _ => True),   -- A
          (fun _ => False),  -- I
          (fun _ => False),  -- B
          (fun _ => True),   -- E
          (fun _ => True),   -- D
          (fun _ => False),  -- Z
          (fun _ => True),   -- K
          (fun _ => False),  -- M
          ?_⟩
  constructor
  · -- Prove Premises
    refine And.intro ?p1 (And.intro ?p2 (And.intro ?p3 (And.intro ?p4 (And.intro ?p5 ?p6))))
    · -- (Z ∧ A) → I
      intro x h
      exact h.1
    · -- (B ∧ A) → ¬ I
      intro x h hi
      exact hi
    · -- A → (Z ∨ K)
      intro x _; exact Or.inr True.intro
    · -- (K ∧ A) → E
      intro x _; exact True.intro
    · -- (K ∧ A) → D
      intro x _; exact True.intro
    · -- (M ∧ A ∧ I) → (B ∧ E)
      intro x h; exact False.elim h.1
  · -- ¬ Conclusion
    intro h
    rcases h with ⟨x, hx⟩
    exact hx.1

-- Model where all premises hold and the conclusion is true
theorem model_true :
  ∃ (U : Type) (A I B E D Z K M : U → Prop),
    Premises U A I B E D Z K M ∧ Conclusion U A I B E D Z K M := by
  refine ⟨Unit,
          (fun _ => False),  -- A
          (fun _ => False),  -- I
          (fun _ => False),  -- B
          (fun _ => True),   -- E
          (fun _ => True),   -- D
          (fun _ => False),  -- Z
          (fun _ => False),  -- K
          (fun _ => True),   -- M
          ?_⟩
  constructor
  · -- Prove Premises
    refine And.intro ?p1 (And.intro ?p2 (And.intro ?p3 (And.intro ?p4 (And.intro ?p5 ?p6))))
    · -- (Z ∧ A) → I
      intro x h; exact h.1
    · -- (B ∧ A) → ¬ I
      intro x h hi; exact hi
    · -- A → (Z ∨ K)
      intro x ha; exact False.elim ha
    · -- (K ∧ A) → E
      intro x h; exact False.elim h.1
    · -- (K ∧ A) → D
      intro x h; exact False.elim h.1
    · -- (M ∧ A ∧ I) → (B ∧ E)
      intro x h; exact False.elim h.2.1
  · -- Conclusion holds: pick the unique element of Unit
    refine ⟨(), ?_⟩
    exact And.intro True.intro (And.intro True.intro True.intro)
